New York Aug. 15th 1847

Rev. and Dear Sir!

In the kind remarks you made in the last number of the Occident, relative to my endeavours in establishing schools for promoting education among the hebrew children in general in this city, you observed, that you were not fully informed, as so the details of my plan of working. I with pleasure send you a copy of the second division of our constitution of the Union School-[?], which will give you some idea of our plans

I feel also happy in acquainting you, that our school is in a flourishing condition, and everything proceeding as favorably as possible in so short a time. We have at present found teachers engaged in the Union School. At the quarterly enunciation held some time since, the answering of the scholars seemed to give general satisfaction, as was e[?] by the parents present. On that occasion we presented the children with an appropriate banner, having the following inscription [Hebrew] Hebrew-Union-School No 1. Hoping soon, to see a vast improvement in the condition of the rising generation of Israelites in this city, I am, as always

Your

obdt servant

D Lilienthal

II Division

Organization of the school.

§33

The school consists of two divisions: of the elementary school in two classes of the mercantile polytechnic school in three classes.

§34

If the means of the society permit it, there can be also established in other parts of the city, when the want of it should call them in existence, branches of the elementary school.

§35

Only such classes will be established in the beginning, as the treasury of the utmost necessity requires the board has the power to form new classes.

Article VII

§36

The elementary school gives the primary education, teaches everything, what is wanted at the entry in the high school.

§37

In the elementary school every boy or girl is accepted, who has attained the age of 5 years. As they get their first schooling here, no examination is needed at their entry. The entry is on the first of every month, the application shall be made to the Super=intendent.

§38

Children with some knowledge can after the examination before the S. I. the teacher enter at once every class, to which they are found worthy.

§39

Every child must have the necessary books stationery.

§40

The plan of study comprises.

1) Religion 2) the elements of the hebrew language

3) the elements of the english language.

4) ciphering.

5) singing delineation, of the means of the society allow such an expenditure.

§41.

the study of religion comprises the explanation of the small catechism, combined with exegesis of the bible the learning by heart of biblical part verses in the study of the Bearadoth the order of the prayer. the teacher must feel the holiness of his calling, in order to penitrate to the tender hearts of his youthful audience to plant in it a conviction love to their faith. It is divided

a) for the lower class [Hebrew]. Knowledge of the order of the daily holyday Sabbath prayers, the history of the Pentateuch till to the giving of the law on Sinai explanation of the Doctrines of faith from the small Catechism.

b) for the higher class. Knowledge of the order of the prayers for the whole year; biblical history all to the destruction of the first temple study of the larger other catechism. An [?] is given every other day for this study

§42.

the elementary study of the hebrew language consists in spelling reading with the proper accentuation, beginning of the grammar, translation of the prayers of Genesis Exodus, hebrew writing.

a) for the lower class. Spelling reading translation of the prayers [Hebrew] [Hebrew] hebrew writing.

b) for the higher class. Grammar, the regular verbs, the nouns and pronouns, Genesis numers hebrew writing.

Three hours are alloted every day to this study. This study should be teached with zeal pleasure, in order that the youth may embrace in love the sources of his religion, and that they may not remain strangers in them.

§43

the elementary study of the english language consists in spelling reading, grammar writing Citography. As this language is that of the country, care must be taken to get good teachers, in order that the children get a good pronunciation and a mine of words.

a) for the lower class. spelling reading, writing the beginning of grammar.

b) for the higher class. Reading, gram[m]ar, declamation, Caligraphy, Citography. Two hours are alloted for it in each class.

§44.

Ciphering consists in the study of the ciphers, the four modes of counting. This study should be combined with practical illustrations, in order that the scholars get used to all sorts of combination. Ciphering by heart.

for the lower class. Study of Ciphers. Addition subtraction

b) for the higher. Multiplication division.

An hour every day is alloted to it, except on friday.

§45

the language, used in all studies, as also in the translation of hebrew is the english language.

§46

the Caligraphy is teached after lithographies in the lower classes after precepts on the tablet.

§47

the teacher keep a daybook.

§48

the curses in every class last two a year a half; if a child makes quicker progress it can be sooner promoted to a higher class with the permission of the board the S. Intendant

§49

Every Pesach Succoth is an public examination Censure in the presence of the board the S I the teachers (for the form see down)

§50

the hours of school, except on Sabbath holy days are during the sum[m]er month from 9-12 A. M. from 2-45 P. M. during winter from 9 am. to 3 P.M.

Article VIII

§51

the mercantile polytechnic school is for the instruction of those, who wish to learn a trade shall prepare them for it. the girls learn here also all the branches of needlework. That religious instruction is one of the chief aims also in this school need not to be told.

§52

All scholars must pass an examination before the board S. I. before they can enter the school, they decide in which class he or she shall enter. Those, who passed the elementary school of the society, can of course enter at once the high school.

§53

Every scholar has to get his own books stationary.

§54

The objects, teached here, are

1) religion preparatory study for the confirmation.

2) hebrew language

3) english

4) mercantile correspondence

5) Single double Entry

6) higher Arithmetic

7) Geography, combined with mercantile Geography

8) history of the U. S.

9) german language

10) Caligraphy

11) Needlework for the girls. At the option of the board the branches of study can be enlarged.

§55

1) Religion:

study of the larger catechism.

jewish history

preparation for confirmation

divided in three classes

a) freshman class. Articles of faith jewish history form the destruction of the first temple till to the close of the talmud.

b) junior class. doctrine of duties and j. history to Mendelsohn

c) senior class. Reparation to confirmation Repetition of biblical jewish history to the present age.

§56

The teacher must feel speak with warmth fire; when it what comes from the heart will reach the heart, the truth of our religion will take a firm hold in the hearts and of the scholars be forever united with all their thoughts actions. the study of religion shall not only be a matter of memory, but the inner man shall be penetrated sanctified by it. To do, that, the teacher himself must be penetrated by it express it by dignity meal[?] piety.

§57

2) the study of he hebrew consists in the hebrew grammar, translations of the Pentateuch Bashi[?], traetats[?] of the Mishnah Gamarah.

a) freshman class. forms of and hebrew Gram[m]ar translations of the bible till pentateuch Josua[?] and judges with some Bashi[?]. Hebrew Ortography reading of the thora.

b) juniors cl. syntax of hebrew grammar application in the analysis of the bible with Rashi[?]. Samuel, kings I II, proverbs 12 smaller prophets. Writing in the hebrew tongue.

c) senior cl. Small exercises in the hebrew tongue the remaining parts of the bible. hours alloted every week.

§.58

As the hebrew tongue is one of the corner stone, to help the foundation of our holy religion untouched, it is the duty of the teachers to go to it with heart hand, when there is only a good foundation laid in the elementary school, it will be an easy task [?] the higher classes.

§59

English language:

a) freshman class. Gram[m]ar till to Syntax, written exercises, partly from what was read or narrated, partly self made thematic. Exercise in reading declamations.

b) junior class. Syntax. study of english litterature with examples from authors, written exercises, to raise the standard of their ideas to adopt them to their study of self thinking.

c) senior class. Continuation of the study of litterature. Exercise in larger themata mercantile correspondence

§60

Arithmetic

a) freshman cl. Continuation of plain Ar. fractions. Rule of three ciphering by heart.

b) junior Cl. Proportions and mercantile calculations

c) senior cl. All sorts of mercantile calculations combined with single double entry.

§61

The application of Combinations from trade bussiness makes the chief study, as it affords a good exercise for the mind, when the themata, to be calculated, are not only difficult on numerical account, but because the scholar has to find out, which sort of calculation is adapted to its solution. the variety of it gives also opportunity to acquire a mechanical skill in it.

§62

Geography.

a) freshman class. General G. the scholar gets a view of the whole earth, learn to use to discern on the maps the lands, waters, mountains [?] The teacher shall make frequent use of the maps narrate tell the natural products general history of every country

b) jun. cl. Geog. of the U. S. combined with the history of it, the synchronistic history of Europe other parts of the world. the scholar shall make maps sometimes at home.

c) sen. cl. Mercantile Geogr.

§63

German language.

a) freshman cl. spelling reading, gramar, study by heart of good examples,

german writing.

b) jun. cl. Gramar. Translations from english in german [?] German conversations

c) sen. cl. German reader Anthology. German written exercises, to be made at home.

§64

The knowledge of foreign languages is of immense benefit to a mercantile com[m]unity, and as a [?] of steamers brings both continents more more in closer contact, whereas the children of the members of our the german congregations have a host of relations in the old country; which all will render the knowledge of the german tongue of great use to our children, therefore it ought to be pleasing duty of the teacher to foster this knowledge by a continual conversation in the german tongue during the hours of such a study, at least with higher classes.

§65

Caligraphy after plates, german, english hebrew. It is the duty of the teacher, of to impart to the children an easy uniform plain hand, without any artificialities.

§65

As the girls have free hours during mercantile talmudical studies, those hours shall be employed for the study of needlework the requisite teachers appointed.

Article IX

§66

Teachers.

the board of directors appoints the numbers the remunerations of the teachers. for the moment is nothing certain concluded, till the society gets more firmly established.

§67

Among the teachers the studies will be so divided , that every teacher will be at that place, where he can be of most use.

§68

If a teacher gets sick or is on furlough, the other teacher have to divide in his duties. The teacher, as soon as he gets unable to attend school, shall make it known to the S. I., in order, that he can make arrangement with the other teachers No teacher has the right to close the school.

§69

the candidates for teachers will be examined by the S. I. in the presence of a Comittee of the board, who make also the contract with the teachers,

§69

The vacancies[?] are.

a) in Nisan during Passover

b) in tishri " Succoth the holy days. also every Sabbath, Schebuoth[?] Purim Tishe be Ab fastdays

Article X

§. 70

Library As soon as the means of the Society permit it, a library shall be collected. One of the teachers shall be appointed librarian by the Directors S. I. who shall keep a catalogue of all works. Every teacher has the right to propose books, which belong to his field, the S. I. will consult them the Directors about it. As at auctions stationers palecable[?] books may sometimes be had at reduced prices, the attention of the teachers is called upon it.

§71

the books shall be partly such, which will help the study of the teachers of such, which can be trusted to the children. A School Library is for now the chief point. The teachers have the right for the library at all times against their written signature; the scholars only on friday, which is also return day where they can get a new book or a renewal of the old one.

Article XI

§72

Discipline

The discipline consists in censures in the preparatory means for that purpose

§73

Every scholar has in his class his appointed place after the combined success in all its branches. Morality industry have also influence in the distribution of the places

§74

the daybook is kept in the following form:

day of the month and week

hours wantingAbsent come toolate Praisegood leisureBad

On every Monday the S. I. looks at the daybook. All excuses must then be rendered, and all praises, punishment or other remarks be given.

§75

the small censures are quarterly in the presence of the board the S. I. the teachers. They consists in general judgments of the teachers on the state of morality zeal of every single one, either praise worthy or reprimanding. The S. I. reads them aloud before all the scholars intermixes with it his exhortations, admonitions punishment. Where the fault lies at home the aid of the parents is necessary to cure the scholar of a mischievous behaviour, a written certificate will be send to the parents, which has to be returned to the school with their signatures.

§76

The large censures are during 1/2 yearly examination then also the advancement in higher classes

§77

the book of censure are thus.

Half yearly testimonial of N. N.

Scholar of Class School

Morality study

Order regularity modesty behavior attention study at home progress remarks

classesSubjects of instruction: Prasident

S. I.

Explanation of notes. Teacher.

This testimonial must be returned with the signature of the parents of guardians on the backside.

§78

the punishments are

a) notes in the daybook

b) standing aside

c) the working apart from the others during school hours

d) corporeal punishment: Confining

Premiums §79

The premiumices for the scholar are left yet to the board of directors the S. I. who will give always such rewards to excellence zeal, as the means of the treasury allow.

§80

Every scholar, who leaves the school, has to tell this intention to the S. I.

Rev. I. Leeser

Philadelphia

Walnut St. 371.
